Here, we explore the possibility of using pristine hexagonal silicon (hex‑Si) monolayers as (photo)catalysts for water splitting. We found that pristine hex‑Si monolayers show promise as H2O activation site, promoting oxygen evolution reaction (OER), and energetically favorable O2 production in both acidic and alkaline media. However, hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and OER on this surface do require a substantial overpotential due to the weak bond between H2O and the pristine hex‑Si monolayer, strong H and OH adsorption on the hex‑Si surface, and the energy needed for OOH binding in both acidic and alkaline conditions. Understanding these findings aids in developing hex‑Si-based (photo)catalysts for future water splitting reactions. Introduction To maximize the efficient production of clean hydrogen, we need effective and durable (photo)catalysts for both hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) applications [1–7]. While (photo)catalysts based on platinum group metals (PGM) meet these criteria [8,9], the challenges [10–14] posed by scarcity of platinum (and other noble metals), high PGM production costs, PGM agglomeration issues, and inadequate stability during reactions have spurred a shift in interests. Researchers also actively pursue abundant (in nature), cost-effective, noble metal-free alternatives [15,16]. Silicon, the second most abundant element in the Earth's crust after oxygen [17], has a rich history of development, esp., its synthesis and diverse applications [18–25]. Notably, porous silicon (p-Si)-based(photo)catalysts, e.g., p-Si/TiO2/M(N5)HA, Au/p-Si, Ag/p-Si, Cu/p-Si, Ni /p-Si [26–32], have attracted some attention. However, results still pale in comparison to PGM. Here, we present results of our computational study of the mechanism behind water splitting with a monolayer of hexagonal silicon (hex‑Si) as the (photo)catalyst. Hex-Si has a regular honeycomb structure, with electron mobility comparable to graphene and silicene (ca. 100 times that of bulk Si) [18,33–35]. This makes hex‑Si a good and simplified control system to model p-Si [15,22,23,25,33] as a (photo)catalyst for water splitting applications. We studied the interaction of H2O, H, OH, O, and OOH, on pristine (defect-free) hex‑Si, and determined the corresponding total energies required for the relevant reactions to occur, both for acidic and alkaline environment (electrolyte). Computational methods We performed spin-polarized, van der Waals (vdW) corrected density functional theory (DFT) based total energy calculations [36–41], using projector augmented waves (PAW) [42] to describe the ion cores, Perdew-Burke-Enzerhoff (PBE) generalized gradient (GGA) exchange correlation functional [43], and a cutoff energy of 400 eV. We adopt the Monkhorst-Pack method [44] to perform the Brillouin zone integrations, with 16×8×1 special k-points. We determined the ground state electronic and geometric properties with the Hellman-Feynman forces converging to −0.01 eV/Å and the energy differences converge to 10 − 5 eV, respectively [45–52]. To construct a monolayer of pristine (defect free) hexagonal Si (hex‑Si), we truncated lonsdaleite silicon (space group P63/mmc) along the [001] direction and fix the Si atoms at their bulk equilibrium coordinates. We use a periodic slab, one atomic layer thick, with 36 Si atoms per layer, separated by 20 Å of vacuum along [001]. After optimization, the pristine hex‑Si has lattice constants a = 3.85 Å and b = 8.90 Å, and a Si-Si bond-length of 2.27 Å. In Fig. 1 , we show the corresponding structure, Brillouin zone, and calculated electronic band structure. We then adsorbed H2O, H, OH, O, and OOH on the pristine hex‑Si, to determine the corresponding total energies and other properties required to understand the relevant reactions necessary for H2 generation at both acidic and alkaline environments (electrolytes) (cf., Table 1 ). We used a (4×3) surface unit of hex‑Si as the supercell for the adsorption system (cf., Fig. 1(a)). This takes care of the unwanted interactions between periodic images of the adsorbates (H2O, H, OH, O, and OOH). We determined the adsorption energies from the change in the total energy of the system with respect the case with the adsorbates (H2O, H, OH, O, and OOH) sufficiently far (ca. 10 Å) from the hex‑Si monolayer. We used the VASPKIT [45] to carry out Bader charge analyses [53–56] and generate other post-calculation data. We used VESTA package [57] to draw the structures and related figures. Results and discussion Water (H2O) splitting on a (photo)catalyst surface can be divided into two half-cell reactions [58], viz., hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). HER entails H2O reduction (cathodic reaction) to yield H2 (2H++ 2e− → H2). On the other hand, OER entails H2O oxidation (anodic reaction, involving four steps of electron and proton transfers [47–50]) to yield O2 (2H2O → O2 + 4H++ 4e − ). The sequence initiates with H2O adsorption on the (photo)catalyst surface, leading to the intermediate production of H+ and hydroxyl radicals. Finally, this cascade culminates with H2 and O2 generation. In general, three major parameters determine HER and OER activity, viz.: (1) the nature of the proton donor, i.e., water (e.g., in alkaline environment) or hydronium (e.g., in acidic environment); (2) the energetics of the intermediate steps leading to H2 formation; and (3) the availability of active sites for the reaction. Optimal HER and OER activities require reasonably stable (adsorption) intermediates on the active sites of the (photo) catalyst surface in preparation for the succeeding steps. H 2 O adsorption on with a monolayer of pristine hex‑Si Fig. 1(c) shows the semimetallic (characterized by the zero-band gap) band structure of a monolayer of pristine hex‑Si. Adsorption of H2O (cf., Fig. 2 (a)—(b)) does not result in any noticeable change in the hex‑Si geometric and electronic band structure (cf., Fig. 2(a)—(b)). Bader charge analysis shows a strongly polar H2O, with ca. −1.22e charged O and ca. +0.62e charge H atoms. Upon adsorption, charge transfer (CT) analyses reveal ca. +0.017e transfer from H2O to the hex‑Si monolayer. Thus, we find that H2O will spontaneously adsorb on hex‑Si, albeit rather weakly (−0.033 eV, cf., Table 1). However, in practice, the actual voltage required may be higher than the thermodynamic equilibrium potential (i.e., > 1.23 V) due to factors such as kinetic barriers, losses in the system, and process efficiency. The potential necessary to drive the entire (four-step) reaction, the overpotential η OER = max [∆Gn )]/e (the maximum value of ∆Gn/e where n = 1,2,3,4), and should be as low as possible. Hydrogen generation using pristine hex‑Si monolayer as (Photo)Catalyst Photocatalysis involves the transfer of solar energy to chemical energy for the production of hydrogen. To promote the breaking of water bonds and the generation of hydrogen, photocatalysts need to possess a sufficiently large band gap. This ensures proper positioning of oxidation and reduction reactions. When incident light carries photon energy higher than or comparable to the band gap of the photocatalyst, valence electrons undergo photoexcitation and depart from the valence band. Electrons in the valence band of the photocatalyst absorb photons of specific wavelengths, exciting them to the conduction band and leaving holes in the valence band. Subsequently, the excited electrons go to surface of the photocatalyst to initiate the HER, while the holes in the valence band migrate to the catalyst's surface to initiate the OER. Both reactions contribute to the overall water splitting process [66–68], leading to the production of H2 and O2. In the preceding sections, we have examined the HER and OER mechanisms for a pristine hex‑Si monolayer (photo)catalysts. It can be inferred that H2 generation generally takes place on this pristine hex‑Si (photo)catalyst. To enhance H2 generation, the conduction band minimum (CBM) of the hex‑Si monolayer surface must exhibit greater reductive capacity and a reduction potential greater than the H2O reduction potential. Similarly, for the production of O2 from H2O, the highest valence band of hex‑Si must be sufficiently reactive in terms of H2O oxidation. This consideration circles back to the band gap issue. The 0 eV band gap of hex‑Si leads to an inefficient HER process. The electrons generated on the pristine hex‑Si surface result in a reduction reaction that is not well-positioned, contributing to a high barrier for H2O reduction potential and a notably high negative Gibbs free energy of adsorbed H. This suggests the need for a sufficiently high overpotential to optimize the reduction process on this surface. Fortuitously, the holes formed at the valence band maximum (VBM) of the in the pristine hex‑Si surface are energetically favorable for the oxidation process. As a result, O2(gas) production occurs spontaneously, with or without overpotentials on this surface. Conclusions We have investigated the mechanism of water splitting on the pristine hex‑Si monolayer surface using DFT study. We found that pristine hex‑Si monolayers show promise as H2O activation site, promoting OER, and energetically favorable O2 production in both acidic and alkaline media. However, HER and OER on this surface do require a substantial over-potential due to the weak bond between H2O and the pristine hex‑Si monolayer, strong H and OH adsorption on the hex‑Si surface, and the energy needed for OOH binding in both acidic and alkaline conditions. Understanding these findings aids in developing hex‑Si-based (photo)catalysts for future water splitting reactions. For example, the adsorption energies of H, OH, O, and OOH to hex‑Si may be readjusted via appropriate surface modifications to reduce these high overpotentials. These studies are now underway. coredata.dc:description: Here, we explore the possibility of using pristine hexagonal silicon (hex‑Si) monolayers as (photo)catalysts for water splitting. We found that pristine hex‑Si monolayers show promise as H2O activation site, promoting oxygen evolution reaction (OER), and energetically favorable O2 production in both acidic and alkaline media. However, hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and OER on this surface do require a substantial overpotential due to the weak bond between H2O and the pristine hex‑Si monolayer, strong H and OH adsorption on the hex‑Si surface, and the energy needed for OOH binding in both acidic and alkaline conditions. Understanding these findings aids in developing hex‑Si-based (photo)catalysts for future water splitting reactions.
